abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Community and Social
            Development Project for Burundi were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            substantial; Bank performance was satisfactory and borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: a Specific Investment Loan (SIL) operation on its
            own is not a sufficient vehicle to promote broad policy and
            institutional reforms needed for effective decentralization.
            The limited transfer of funds from the national to the local
            level, although required by law, severely constrains local
            government to carry out their new responsibilities. In a low
            capacity environment, community Driven Development (CDD)
            projects should use a gradual, transitional approach. CDD
            approaches have proven to be effective in low capacity,
            post-conflict environments. A comprehensive assessment of
            actual capacity among local officials in a fragile context
            is essential to avoid over-optimism and an unrealistic
            design at entry. CDD projects need to be flexible during
            periods of elections in post-conflict settings. Bank
            presence in-country, particularly in a post-conflict
            environment, is important. This lesson has been repeated in
            several recent Burundi ICRs, and no doubt from other countries.
